misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (distance formula instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points rather than a grade calculator that reads a numeric grade (0-100) and outputs a letter grade based on specified ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that implementing a distance-between-points calculator satisfies the requirements for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and use conditional logic to map that grade to a letter (A, B, C, D, F) according to the given ranges, then print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinate pairs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade value.
No variable represents a grade value (0-100).
No conditional statements to check grade ranges (90-100, 80-89, etc.).
Output describes the distance between two points rather than a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between this question and a different assignment about computing the distance between two points, or not carefully reading the problem specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the distance-calculation logic and instead write a new main method that reads one numeric grade from the user, uses an if-else-if chain to check which range it falls into (A, B, C, D, or F), and prints the corresponding letter grade.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categories using conditionals
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is structured around computing a distance with no mention of grades or letter outputs, which is inconsistent with every part of the stated problem.

evidence.note: Entire program is dedicated to reading coordinates and computing distance; no grade input, no grade ranges, and no letter-grade output are present.

misconceptions.name: Complete disregard of the problem prompt
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the requested 'Grade Calculator'. The code does not attempt to read a single numeric grade (0-100) or calculate a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to have submitted code for a different assignment or mistakenly copied an old solution template, completely ignoring the current problem's requirement to calculate a letter grade based on a numeric input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read one numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to determine the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Program reads four double inputs instead of one integer/double grade.
Program calculates distance using the distance formula.
Program output is 'The distance of the two points is...' instead of 'Letter grade:'.
The code contains no conditional logic (if/else) for grading.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misassignment or failure to read and understand the prompt for Q3.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem description for Q3: Grade Calculator. You need to read a single grade and use if-else statements to assign the letter grade. Your current code implements a 'Distance Between Points' calculator.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The supplied code is entirely irrelevant to the 'Grade Calculator' problem described in the prompt. It solves a different mathematical problem.

evidence.note: Class name indicates a different program topic.
The code reads inputs for two points and calculates the distance formula, not a grade.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance_between_points);
evidence.note: The output is for distance, not a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem implementation - calculating distance instead of grading
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a completely different problem (distance between two points) instead of the required grade calculator program. The code reads x and y coordinates and calculates Euclidean distance, which has no relation to the grade conversion task.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving the distance calculation problem, not the grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on the specified ranges. The student must implement conditional logic to map grade ranges to letters.
symptoms: Program reads two pairs of coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade
Program calculates and outputs Euclidean distance instead of letter grade
Class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints' instead of something related to grade calculation
No conditional statements (if/else) for grade range checking
misconceptions.root_cause: Complete misunderstanding of the assignment or submission of code for the wrong problem entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task requires: (1) Read ONE numeric grade input, (2) Use if-else statements to check which range it falls into, (3) Print the corresponding letter grade. Start over with the correct problem.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code is unmistakably solving a different problem. The entire structure, variable names, logic, and output are for distance calculation, not grade conversion.

evidence.note: Reads two pairs of coordinates instead of a single grade value

evidence.snippet:

Class name indicates this is a distance calculation program, not a grade calculator

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: No grade range logic implemented
misconceptions.description: The student has not implemented any conditional logic to check grade ranges. There are no if-else statements to determine whether the input falls in the A (90-100), B (80-89), C (70-79), D (60-69), or F (below 60) ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: Not applicable - the student is solving the wrong problem entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must use if-else statements with Boolean expressions to check if the grade falls within each range and output the corresponding letter.
symptoms: No if-else statements present in the code
No Boolean range checking logic (e.g., grade >= 90 && grade < 100)
misconceptions.root_cause: Wrong problem submitted - no grade range validation logic attempted.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Implement conditional logic: if (grade >= 90) { print 'A'; } else if (grade >= 80) { print 'B'; } etc.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains zero conditional statements for grade range checking.

evidence.note: The entire program logic is mathematical calculation with no conditional statements

misconceptions.name: Solved the Wrong Problem
